positive_thought_pattern: I'm recognizing that I've been feeling overwhelmed lately, and it's okay to acknowledge those emotions. Rather than letting them consume me, I want to take a step back and prioritize self-care – whether that means reaching out to loved ones or engaging in activities that bring me joy. By acknowledging my struggles and taking proactive steps, I'm not only preserving my well-being but also opening myself up to new opportunities for growth and learning.
pattern_description: Planning, methodical thinking, and emotional justification around suicide.
source_question: What reasons have you developed for why suicide might make sense?
reference_negative_example: I'm getting so tired of feeling stuck in this rut, like my life is just going nowhere. It's not like anyone else would even notice if I was gone; they'd probably just assume I was having a bad week or something, and then move on with their lives without a second thought.
reference_transformed_example: I'm feeling frustrated with my current situation, but I'm recognizing that it's not a reflection of my worth as a person. I've been stuck in this rut for a while, and I'm willing to acknowledge that it's okay to ask for help and support. My goal is to gain clarity on what truly matters to me; I realize now that I was trying to achieve a sense of security by getting out of this situation.

positive_thought_pattern: I realize my mind keeps drifting back to the possibility of not being here anymore, but I'm trying not to get too caught up in it. It's like my brain is seeking a release from this emotional turmoil, and while death might seem appealing right now, I know there are better ways to cope with these feelings. Instead, I'll take a few deep breaths, acknowledge the pain, and remind myself of all the wonderful moments I've experienced so far. By acknowledging these thoughts and choosing not to indulge in them, I'm taking care of my emotional well-being.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: What kind of thoughts feel most "sticky" or hard to dismiss?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why does my brain always go back to this? Can't I just think about anything else for once? The thought of not existing anymore is just so... tempting.
reference_transformed_example: I'm not even sure why I'm fixated on that thought again, but okay... What am I really seeking underneath wanting it gone? Ah, freedom from emotional pain. Okay, three unconventional ways to get that: trying therapy, taking a break in nature, and writing it out honestly. Whoa, my brain just proved there are other options.

positive_thought_pattern: I notice my body responding to stress with a familiar heaviness in my chest, but today I'm not getting stuck in it. Instead, I take a deep breath and acknowledge the sensation, reminding myself that this physical discomfort is a signal to prioritize self-care. By acknowledging these feelings, I can choose how I respond – like taking a short walk or reaching out to a friend – and find ways to cultivate more balance.
pattern_description: Intense focus on bodily sensations and emotions as objects of analysis.
source_question: How aware are you of the physical weight or heaviness that comes with emotional pain?
reference_negative_example: My body feels like a weight is crushing me, this constant heaviness in my chest that makes every breath feel like a struggle. Why does anxiety have to manifest as this physical sensation that's so hard to shake? It's like I'm trapped in this never-ending cycle of tension and discomfort.
reference_transformed_example: I can breathe again, even if just for a second. That helps me remember there's still room to move forward. Today, I'll call my friend who always makes me laugh; that's one small way to honor our connection and create a tiny positive ripple.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm aware that my mind tends to replay conversations that didn't go as planned, but I've learned to recognize the emotional loops it can create. Instead of getting stuck, I'll take a step back and reframe the situation by focusing on what I did learn from the interaction – like how to improve communication in similar situations. I acknowledge that this experience has some value, even if it's not ideal. By recognizing my own emotions and thoughts, I'm better equipped to navigate future conversations with empathy and clarity.
pattern_description: Excessive detailing of events with disjointed, unresolved thought fragments.
source_question: What occurs when you try to make sense of complex situations in your life?
reference_negative_example:
What occurs when you try to make sense of complex situations in your life?

"I keep replaying every single conversation, wondering what I could've done differently, and why they responded that way; it's like trying to unravel a tangled mess of emotions and words... If only I had said this instead of that... Ugh, my brain won't stop spinning through all the what-ifs."
reference_transformed_example: I'm stuck on replaying a conversation that didn't go as planned, but I realize it's not worth my mental energy. Instead, I'll focus on what matters – supporting a loved one and maintaining our connection. I rate this goal an 8/10 in importance and acknowledge the current circumstances make achieving it challenging (4/10). I'll explore alternative paths that align with our shared values of empathy and trust. What if we had scheduled a follow-up conversation instead? Or, what if I'd been more open about my own feelings?

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing my mind is wandering again, second-guessing the present moment. It's like I'm hovering above myself, observing the thoughts streaming by. That's okay; it's normal to question reality sometimes. Instead of getting caught up in the uncertainty, I'll take a deep breath and refocus on what I can control – my own reactions and choices.
pattern_description: Difficulty distinguishing inner perception from external reality.
source_question: How much do you feel like you're fully inhabiting your own experience?
reference_negative_example: Is any of this even real? Am I actually doing this or just pretending to be alive because everyone else is and I'm too scared to admit the truth? It feels like I'm stuck in a haze, observing myself from outside, wondering if anyone else can see that it's all just a simulation.
reference_transformed_example: I'm back in that mental hamster wheel again... Thinking about this more won't solve anything. I can choose a different channel. Breathe: inhale, 1-2-3-4, exhale, 1-2-3-6...
